title: Atomiswave
text:
The Atomiswave is a custom <a href="arcade%20system%20board">arcade system board</a> and <a href="arcade%20cabinet">cabinet</a> from <a href="Sammy%20Corporation">Sammy Corporation</a>. It is based on Sega's <a href="Sega%20Dreamcast">Dreamcast</a> console, sharing similarities with the <a href="Sega%20NAOMI">NAOMI</a>, 
as far as it uses interchangeable <a href="game%20cartridge">game cartridge</a>s, as well as a removable module for changing the control scheme (including dual <a href="joystick">joystick</a>s, dual <a href="light%20gun">light gun</a>s and a <a href="steering%20wheel">steering wheel</a>), but unlike the NAOMI, the Atomiswave doesn't feature expanded RAM compared to the Dreamcast.
With the retirement of the aging <a href="Neo%20Geo%20%28console%29">Neo Geo MVS</a> system, <a href="SNK%20Playmore">SNK Playmore</a> chose the Atomiswave as its next system to develop games for. In a contract with <a href="Sammy%20Corporation">Sammy</a>, SNK Playmore agreed to develop five games for the Atomiswave system. "<a href="Metal%20Slug%206">Metal Slug 6</a>" was SNK Playmore's fifth game for the Atomiswave, after which SNK moved on to a <a href="Taito%20Type%20X">Taito Type X</a>2 arcade board.
AW-net.
In Japan, the Atomiswave was able to connect via a special modem to the AW-Net online system set up by Sammy. The AW-Net was primarily used to play online with other players and to create online player rankings. AW-Net was discontinued on 30 November 2006 following the merger of Sammy and Sega; the follow-up system was <a href="ALL.Net">ALL.Net</a>.
